  2. Language

  4. Identifiers

2.1.2. Identifiers

You use variables as symbolic names for values in your application. The names of variables, called identifiers, conform to certain rules.

Identifiers start with an alphabetic character or the symbol _ followed by any number of alphabetic characters, _ or digits [0-9]. ZScript is a case sensitive language meaning that the lowercase and uppercase representation of the same alphabetic character are considered different characters. For instance, foo, Foo and FOo are treated as 3 distinct identifiers.

You can use most Unicode letters such as å and ü in identifiers. (For more details, see the lexical grammar reference.)

Some examples of legal names are Number_hits, temp99 and _name.

Reserved words

These keywords cannot be used as identifiers for variables, functions, classes, etc. anywhere in ZScript source.

  • array
  • auto
  • bool
  • char
  • float
  • int
  • string
  • table
  • typed_array
  • var
  • and
  • base
  • break
  • case
  • catch
  • class
  • const
  • constructor
  • continue
  • default
  • delete
  • destructor
  • do
  • else
  • enum
  • export
  • extends
  • false
  • final
  • for
  • foreach
  • function
  • global
  • if
  • import
  • in
  • include
  • inout
  • none
  • not
  • null
  • or
  • return
  • static
  • super
  • switch
  • this
  • throw
  • true
  • try
  • typeid
  • typeof
  • void
  • while
  • with
  • xor
Identifiers with special meanings A few identifiers have a special meaning in some contexts without being reserved words of any kind. They include:
  • rawset
  • rawget
  • rawcall
  • @expr
  • @inject
  • @scope
